III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207 Staff responsibilities
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be directly
Description responsible for all the following activities: (a) Placing and
supervising children in out-of-home care. Social service workers
shall work directly with the children, their families, and other
relevant individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service plans for the
children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster Care worker is not assisting with reunification services or
maintaining communication.
Investigation Interviews:
On 7/28/25 Parent 1 reported to DCWL that their child was
removed from Parent 2 in November 2024. The child was initially
placed with Parent 1, then removed by MDHHS Children’s
Services due to Parent 1’s criminal history record. The child was
placed in foster care and the agency did not make any efforts to
assist Parent 1 with classes and did not return phone calls. Parent
1 stated this had been occurring for two years and contributed to
Parent 1 repeatedly “losing” in court. Parent 1 was contacted by
email on 7/28/25, 7/29/25, 8/1/25, and 8/27/25. Parent 1 did not
have a working phone number. In each email contact DCWL
Consultant requested to schedule a phone interview. However,
Parent 1 never responded to phone interview requests. In an
email on 8/1/25 Parent 1 reported he tried to reach out to Foster
Care Worker and Foster Care Supervisor, but they did not
respond. Parent 1 reported his biggest concern was his child was
initially placed in his care, then removed and has not been
returned. Parent 1 clarified these actions occurred with MDHHS
Children’s Services, prior to the case moving to Wellspring. Parent
1 was informed DCWL was unable to investigate actions
completed by MDHHS Children’s Services. Parent 1 was provided
with contact information for resources that may help with those
concerns. Parent 1 was informed the DCWL investigation focuses
on Child Placing Agency rule compliance and whether there was a
lack of effort by the agency to actively implement the treatment
plan. DCWL Consultant requested for Parent 1 to provide any
documentation or specific information about calls that were not
returned, or services not provided. However, Parent 1 did not
respond to these requests.
2

On 8/28/25 Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) was interviewed via
video call. FCS reported they received the foster care case on
12/12/23. The case has been assigned to Foster Care Worker
(FCW) since that time. FCS stated she was unaware of any
services or referrals that had been missed. All service referrals
were provided to Parent 1 and documentation uploaded into
MiSACWIS. FCS stated she was unaware of any time that FCW
missed contacts with Parent 1. FCS indicated that case contacts
in MiSACWIS would show that FCW had contact with Parent 1
more frequently than the monthly requirement. FCS stated that
Parent 1 has not been consistently active in services such as
counseling, drug screens, sober living, and parenting class.
Parent 1 was previously referred to parenting class and
discharged ‘unsuccessfully’. As parents can only be referred
twice, the agency determined a second referral will not be made
until Parent 1 showed consistency in completing other treatment
plan items. The agency did not want to refer Parent 1 at a time
when they knew he was not likely to successfully complete the
program, due to other barriers. Parent 1’s communication with the
agency was inconsistent and he refused to allow staff into his
home. While he was not considered ‘absent’ he was evasive and
would not respond to the agency at times. FCS stated Parent 1
made complaints to the agency before and was provided with the
grievance policy but did not submit a grievance. FCS reported
that FCW is an excellent staff and there have never been any
concerns about his work, nor had there been any disciplinary
action.
On 8/29/25 Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed via video
call. FCW reported he began working with Parent 1 in December
2023. FCW reported that communication had been poor on Parent
1’s end. Parent 1 had been non-responsive at times or had a
phone that was not working/out of service or had changed his
number without informing the agency. FCW stated he has not met
with Parent 1 face-to-face since December 2024. Several
appointments had been scheduled, only to have Parent 1 cancel
at the last minute. FCW stated he made several attempts to speak
with Parent 1 and typically attempts to communicate with him on a
bi-weekly basis.
Parent 1 was provided with foster care supportive visitation but
had several missed appointments and was discharged from the
program. Parent 1 reported to FCW his absences were due to
feeling uncomfortable having visits in public as he believed
MDHHS Children’s Services’ staff were stalking him. Parent 1
provided FCW with photos of several license plates he believed
3

were ‘stalkers’ because they had similar letters on them, FCW
stated none of the plates belonged to state cars and were likely
not MDHHS staff. FCW stated Parent 1 has been refusing
services, which is concerning as he recently seemed paranoid and
indicated he had been hallucinating. FCW reported he has been
very honest with Parent 1 about not referring to the parenting
program again at this time, as only two referrals can be made.
FCW told Parent 1 he was concerned that a referral now may not
be in his best interest, due to his lack of transportation, frequent
cancelling of appointments, and lack of participation in other
services. FCW did not want to set Parent 1 up for failure. FCW
reported that he had tried to have Parent 1 participate in drug
screens and therapy. But Parent 1 did not follow through on these
services. FCW offered virtual options for Parent 1 to complete an
assessment intake and attend therapy, but Parent 1 declined.
Parent 1 stated he did not want to open up to anyone or share his
information. Parent 1 later told FCW that he obtained therapy
services online and provided FCW with information from several
different therapists. FCW informed Parent 1 that he needed to
consistently see one therapist in order to properly assess and
evaluate his progress. Parent 1 reported he had a new therapist
but has yet to provide any verification.
FCW stated overall, he continues to try to engage with Parent 1.
However, Parent 1 always has an excuse for why he cannot
complete services or meet. Parent 1 told the court that the agency
was not assisting with drug screens. FCW reached out to an
MDHHS office that was closer to Parent 1, in order to make travel
easier. FCW also arranged for a case aid to assist with
transportation to drug screens after parenting time. However,
every time the case aid would attempt to transport Parent 1, he
had an excuse why he could not do it that day. FCW scheduled a
meeting with Parent 1 for 8/20/25 to discuss the situation, but
Parent 1 canceled that morning. FCW offered to reschedule but
did not receive a response from Parent 1. FCW noted after the
recent court hearing, Parent 1’s attorney reported he could not
reach his client. Parent 1’s phone number did not appear to be
active.
Documents reviewed
Parent 1 provided a two-page typed document via email, outlining
information regarding his case. Parent 1 did not indicate who
authored the document, or if the two pages were part of a larger
document. Overall, there were concerns outlined with MDHHS
Children’s Services, Parent 1’s former attorney, and a
4

psychologist who took longer than necessary to complete an
evaluation. Regarding the agency, it was stated that:
• Foster Care Worker would not provide transportation for
Parent 1 but later offered transportation.
• Foster Care Worker made a recommendation in court on
an unspecified date that was different from what he
originally told Parent 1.
• The August 2024 court hearing ordered for parenting time
visits to move to Allegan County, but that has not
happened.
• A court order on an unspecified date ordered parenting
time to be increased from the 2 hours per week plan, but
that has not happened.
• Parent 1 completed two parenting classes, which the
agency said was enough, then asked the court to order
more.
• The 5/28/25 and 5/30/25 drug screens should be
inadmissible as they did not have Parent 1’s signature.
A review of the MiSACWIS case record found the following
relevant information:
• Case accepted by agency on 12/12/23
• Foster care case contacts were reviewed from Dec 2023 to
August 2025. Foster Care Worker completed or attempted
monthly phone/text and face to face contacts with Parent 1.
• Case contacts confirmed information reported by FCW
regarding attempted phone and face-to-face contacts,
attempts to change drug screening location, parenting class
dismissal, and transportation assistance.
• Court order from August 2024 indicated “DHHS shall make
reasonable efforts to assist father with transportation to
visits and/or arrange for visits at Allegan DHHS and/or
virtual visits ASAP”. The order did not specifically state
visits had to occur in Allegan.
• Court orders were reviewed as Parent 1 indicated there
was an order to increase parenting time. This information
was not found. However, it was noted that court orders
indicated an increase in parenting time at the agency’s
discretion, when progress has been made with services.
• Parent Agency Treatment Plans identified several strengths
for Parent 1, including sufficient financial skills, intellectual
capability, physical health, social support system,
understanding of childcare, and housing. However, the
housing had not been verified since August 2024, due to
Parent 1 canceling scheduled visits. Areas of need were
identified as parenting skills, resource/availability
management, employment, substance abuse, emotional
5

stability behavior, domestic relations, and
communication/interpersonal skills. The assessment of
these areas appears to be consistent with information
contained in the case file.
• Parent 1 was documented to have participated virtually in
Family Team Meetings to discuss case services on 1/8/24
and 3/12/25. Parent 1 was invited to, but did not attend
Family Team Meetings on 4/9/24, 6/17/24, 9/23/24,
5/12/25, and 8/20/25.
• Referral for counseling services was completed on 3/12/24.
• Supportive visitation and in-home parent education referral
completed on 1/6/25. On 2/18/25 Parent 1 cancelled the
intake scheduled for that day. The only documented face-
to-face occurred on 2/27/25. Several scheduled
appointments were canceled by Parent 1 on the day of the
appointment.
• Regarding Parent 1’s concerns about the drug screens
from 5/28/25 and 5/30/25, no screen results were located in
the file.
• Parenting Time Safety Plan date 12/12/24 and signed by
Parent 1 indicated the following plan:
o Relative caregivers can supervise parenting times in
relative home or in community.
o Parenting time twice per week, for one hour. Parent
1 could request longer visits with approval from the
agency.
o Parent 1 cannot visit outside of designated time.
o Court orders must be followed. Visits outside of
parenting time or not approved by agency may risk
placement
o No unsupervised visits for Parent 1.
o Relative caregivers will notify worker when visits
take place and give brief description of visit.
o If emergency arises, caregivers will contact law
enforcement or agency.
Analysis No violation was found. Based on interviews and review of
documentation in the case file, there was no indication agency
staff failed to assist Parent 1 in reunification services.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
